what helps increase the osmotic pressure of the blood?
why does osmotic pressure is proportional to the number of solute present? i dont get it!!

Think of it this way. The more water you consume, the more water will leave your blood vessels. And if you have less water within your vessels, well then the osmotic pressure will drop. You can do an experiment: fill a balloon with water and place it into a container filled with salt water. Once you immerse the balloon, water in the balloon will begin to travel out of the balloon and into the container. A similar thing happens to your blood vessels.

You can think of the osmotic pressure as the quantity of pressure that is required to stop osmosis from taking place.

there are more particles in 50 grams of hydrogen than 50 grams of boron. Therefore, since there are more particles, the osmotic pressure is higher. Hope that helps!

Hey! Sorry it took so long to respond. The website would be a better place to ask question. Recall that osmotic pressure is a colligative property, which means that it depends on the number of particles. As you lower the molecular weight (while keeping the mass and volume constant), you increase the number of particles. Suppose you have 50 grams of hydrogen and 50 grams of boron... Are there more particles in 50 grams of boron or hydrogen? Since hydrogen has a smaller molecular weight,

Super loaded question. There are many direct and indirect ways that our body regulates the osmotic and hydrostatic pressure within the capillaries of our body. The short and less complicated answer is, the higher the concentrations of various solutes (proteins, etc) inside the blood is, the higher the osmotic pressure is.
